clean_story: Choosing between options.  Shaping what happens next. "Decision" comes from Latin decidere—to "cut off," like slicing away alternatives to leave one path. Most see decisions as moments of clarity, but they’re often messy collisions of instinct, habit, and incomplete information. Like a chef tasting soup mid-recipe—adjusting salt without the final flavor in mind. The brain doesn’t weigh options like a scale. It predicts outcomes using dopamine spikes, past mistakes, and even gut bacteria signals. A 2012 study found people’s choices shift when their hands are warm versus cold—unconscious cues hijacking logic. Take split-second decisions:A goalkeeper diving left or right during a penalty kick has a 33% chance of success—yet pros "feel" the right direction in under 0. 1 seconds. Their brains aren’t calculating probabilities; they’re matching patterns from thousands of past kicks. Even "rational" choices rely on shortcuts. Buying a house?Most pick based on two emotional triggers: "Does it feel like home?" and "Can I picture my furniture here?"Spreadsheets come later—justifying the gut call. The hidden labor of deciding isn’t the choice itself, but the editing afterward. Memories rewrite to fit the narrative of "I meant to do that. "Regret isn’t about bad outcomes—it’s about realizing you ignored your own signals. Three related subjects are cognitive biases, how stress rewires choices, and why groups decide worse than individuals.
